segment.source: How to Move the MBAM 2.5 Databases
segment.target: How to Move the MBAM 2.5 Databases

segment.source: How to Move the MBAM 2.5 Databases
segment.target: How to Move the MBAM 2.5 Databases

segment.source: How to Move the MBAM 2.5 Databases
segment.target: How to Move the MBAM 2.5 Databases

segment.source: Use these procedures to move the following databases from one computer to another, that is, to move the databases from Server A to Server B:
segment.target: Use these procedures to move the following databases from one computer to another, that is, to move the databases from Server A to Server B:

segment.source: Compliance and Audit Database
segment.target: Compliance and Audit Database

segment.source: Recovery Database
segment.target: Recovery Database

segment.source: If you are moving multiple features, move them in the following order:
segment.target: If you are moving multiple features, move them in the following order:

segment.source: Recovery Database
segment.target: Recovery Database

segment.source: Compliance and Audit Database
segment.target: Compliance and Audit Database

segment.source: Reports
segment.target: Reports

segment.source: Administration and Monitoring Website
segment.target: Administration and Monitoring Website

segment.source: Self-Service Portal
segment.target: Self-Service Portal

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: To run the example Windows PowerShell scripts provided in this topic, you must update the Windows PowerShell execution policy to enable scripts to be run.
segment.target: To run the example Windows PowerShell scripts provided in this topic, you must update the Windows PowerShell execution policy to enable scripts to be run.

segment.source: See Running Windows PowerShell Scripts for instructions.
segment.target: See Running Windows PowerShell Scripts for instructions.

segment.source: Moving the Recovery Database
segment.target: Moving the Recovery Database

segment.source: The high-level steps for moving the Recovery Database are:
segment.target: The high-level steps for moving the Recovery Database are:

segment.source: Stop all instances of the MBAM Administration and Monitoring Website
segment.target: Stop all instances of the MBAM Administration and Monitoring Website

segment.source: Back up the Recovery Database on Server A
segment.target: Back up the Recovery Database on Server A

segment.source: Install MBAM Server software and run the MBAM Server Configuration wizard on Server B
segment.target: Install MBAM Server software and run the MBAM Server Configuration wizard on Server B

segment.source: Move the Recovery Database from Server A to Server B
segment.target: Move the Recovery Database from Server A to Server B

segment.source: Restore the Recovery Database on Server B
segment.target: Restore the Recovery Database on Server B

segment.source: Configure access to the Database on Server B and update connection data
segment.target: Configure access to the Database on Server B and update connection data

segment.source: Resume the instance of the Administration and Monitoring Website
segment.target: Resume the instance of the Administration and Monitoring Website

segment.source: How to move the Recovery Database
segment.target: How to move the Recovery Database

segment.source: Stop all instances of the MBAM Administration and Monitoring Website
segment.target: Stop all instances of the MBAM Administration and Monitoring Website

segment.source: On each server that is running the MBAM Administration and Monitoring Server Website, use the Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager console to stop the Administration and Monitoring Website.
segment.target: On each server that is running the MBAM Administration and Monitoring Server Website, use the Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager console to stop the Administration and Monitoring Website.

segment.source: To automate this procedure, you can use Windows PowerShell to enter a command that is similar to the following:
segment.target: To automate this procedure, you can use Windows PowerShell to enter a command that is similar to the following:

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: To run this command, you must add the Internet Information Services (IIS) module for Windows PowerShell to the current instance of Windows PowerShell.
segment.target: To run this command, you must add the Internet Information Services (IIS) module for Windows PowerShell to the current instance of Windows PowerShell.

segment.source: Install MBAM Server software and run the MBAM Server Configuration wizard on Server B
segment.target: Install MBAM Server software and run the MBAM Server Configuration wizard on Server B

segment.source: Install the MBAM 2.5 Server software on Server B. For instructions, see Installing the MBAM 2.5 Server Software.
segment.target: Install the MBAM 2.5 Server software on Server B. For instructions, see Installing the MBAM 2.5 Server Software.

segment.source: On Server B, start the MBAM Server Configuration wizard, click Add New Features, and then select only the Recovery Database feature.
segment.target: On Server B, start the MBAM Server Configuration wizard, click Add New Features, and then select only the Recovery Database feature.

segment.source: Alternatively, you can use the Enable-MbamDatabase Windows PowerShell cmdlet to configure the Recovery Database.
segment.target: Alternatively, you can use the Enable-MbamDatabase Windows PowerShell cmdlet to configure the Recovery Database.

segment.source: For instructions on how to configure the databases, see How to Configure the MBAM 2.5 Databases.
segment.target: For instructions on how to configure the databases, see How to Configure the MBAM 2.5 Databases.

segment.source: Back up the Recovery Database on Server A
segment.target: Back up the Recovery Database on Server A

segment.source: Use the Back Up task in SQL Server Management Studio to back up the Recovery Database on Server A. By default, the database name is MBAM Recovery Database.
segment.target: Use the Back Up task in SQL Server Management Studio to back up the Recovery Database on Server A. By default, the database name is MBAM Recovery Database.

segment.source: To automate this procedure, create a SQL file (.sql) that contains the following SQL script, and change the MBAM Recovery Database to use the full recovery mode:
segment.target: To automate this procedure, create a SQL file (.sql) that contains the following SQL script, and change the MBAM Recovery Database to use the full recovery mode:

segment.source: Use the following value to replace the values in the code example with values that match your environment.
segment.target: Use the following value to replace the values in the code example with values that match your environment.

segment.source: $PASSWORD$ - password that you will use to encrypt the Private Key file.
segment.target: $PASSWORD$ - password that you will use to encrypt the Private Key file.

segment.source: Run the script that is stored in the .sql file by using a Windows PowerShell command that is similar to the following:
segment.target: Run the script that is stored in the .sql file by using a Windows PowerShell command that is similar to the following:

segment.source: Use the following value to replace the values in the code example with values that match your environment:
segment.target: Use the following value to replace the values in the code example with values that match your environment:

segment.source: $SERVERNAME$$SQLINSTANCENAME$ - server name and instance from which the Recovery Database will be backed up.
segment.target: $SERVERNAME$$SQLINSTANCENAME$ - server name and instance from which the Recovery Database will be backed up.

segment.source: Move the Recovery Database from Server A to Server B
segment.target: Move the Recovery Database from Server A to Server B

segment.source: Use Windows Explorer to move the MBAM Compliance Status Database Data.bak file from Server A to Server B.
segment.target: Use Windows Explorer to move the MBAM Compliance Status Database Data.bak file from Server A to Server B.

segment.source: To automate this procedure, you can use Windows PowerShell to run a command that is similar to the following:
segment.target: To automate this procedure, you can use Windows PowerShell to run a command that is similar to the following:

segment.source: Use the information in the following table to replace the values in the code example with values that match your environment.
segment.target: Use the information in the following table to replace the values in the code example with values that match your environment.

segment.source: Parameter
segment.target: Parameter

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: $SERVERNAME$
segment.target: $SERVERNAME$

segment.source: Name of the server to which the files will be copied.
segment.target: Name of the server to which the files will be copied.

segment.source: $DESTINATIONSHARE$
segment.target: $DESTINATIONSHARE$

segment.source: Name of the share and path to which the files will be copied.
segment.target: Name of the share and path to which the files will be copied.

segment.source: Restore the Recovery Database on Server B
segment.target: Restore the Recovery Database on Server B

segment.source: Restore the Recovery Database on Server B by using the Restore Database task in SQL Server Management Studio.
segment.target: Restore the Recovery Database on Server B by using the Restore Database task in SQL Server Management Studio.

segment.source: When the previous task finishes, select From Device, and then select the database backup file.
segment.target: When the previous task finishes, select From Device, and then select the database backup file.

segment.source: Use the Add command to select the MBAM Recovery Database Data.bak file, and click OK to complete the restoration process.
segment.target: Use the Add command to select the MBAM Recovery Database Data.bak file, and click OK to complete the restoration process.

segment.source: To automate this procedure, create a SQL file (.sql) that contains the following SQL script:
segment.target: To automate this procedure, create a SQL file (.sql) that contains the following SQL script:

segment.source: Use the following value to replace the values in the code example with values that match your environment.
segment.target: Use the following value to replace the values in the code example with values that match your environment.

segment.source: $PASSWORD$ - password that you used to encrypt the Private Key file.
segment.target: $PASSWORD$ - password that you used to encrypt the Private Key file.

segment.source: Run the script that is stored in the .sql file by using a Windows PowerShell command that is similar to the following:
segment.target: Run the script that is stored in the .sql file by using a Windows PowerShell command that is similar to the following:

segment.source: Use the following value to replace the values in the code example with values that match your environment.
segment.target: Use the following value to replace the values in the code example with values that match your environment.

segment.source: $SERVERNAME$$SQLINSTANCENAME$ - Server name and instance to which the Recovery Database will be restored.
segment.target: $SERVERNAME$$SQLINSTANCENAME$ - Server name and instance to which the Recovery Database will be restored.

segment.source: Configure access to the Database on Server B and update connection data
segment.target: Configure access to the Database on Server B and update connection data

segment.source: Verify that the Microsoft SQL Server user login that enables Recovery Database access on the restored database is mapped to the access account that you provided during the configuration process.
segment.target: Verify that the Microsoft SQL Server user login that enables Recovery Database access on the restored database is mapped to the access account that you provided during the configuration process.

segment.source: If the login is not the same, create a login by using SQL Server Management Studio, and map it to the existing database user.
segment.target: If the login is not the same, create a login by using SQL Server Management Studio, and map it to the existing database user.

segment.source: On the server that is running the Administration and Monitoring Website, use the Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager console to update the connection string information for the MBAM websites.
segment.target: On the server that is running the Administration and Monitoring Website, use the Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager console to update the connection string information for the MBAM websites.

segment.source: Edit the following registry key: HKLMSoftwareMicrosoftMBAM ServerWebRecoveryDBConnectionString
segment.target: Edit the following registry key: HKLMSoftwareMicrosoftMBAM ServerWebRecoveryDBConnectionString

segment.source: Update the Data Source value with the name of the server and instance (for example, $SERVERNAME$$SQLINSTANCENAME) to which the Recovery Database was moved.
segment.target: Update the Data Source value with the name of the server and instance (for example, $SERVERNAME$$SQLINSTANCENAME) to which the Recovery Database was moved.

segment.source: Update the Initial Catalog value with the recovered database name.
segment.target: Update the Initial Catalog value with the recovered database name.

segment.source: To automate this process, you can use the Windows PowerShell command prompt to enter a command line on the Administration and Monitoring Server that is similar to the following:
segment.target: To automate this process, you can use the Windows PowerShell command prompt to enter a command line on the Administration and Monitoring Server that is similar to the following:

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: This connection string is shared by all local MBAM web applications.
segment.target: This connection string is shared by all local MBAM web applications.

segment.source: Therefore, it needs to be updated only once per server.
segment.target: Therefore, it needs to be updated only once per server.

segment.source: Use the following table to replace the values in the code example with values that match your environment.
segment.target: Use the following table to replace the values in the code example with values that match your environment.

segment.source: Parameter
segment.target: Parameter

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: $SERVERNAME$SQLINSTANCENAME$
segment.target: $SERVERNAME$SQLINSTANCENAME$

segment.source: Server name and instance of SQL Server where the Recovery Database is located.
segment.target: Server name and instance of SQL Server where the Recovery Database is located.

segment.source: $DATABASE$
segment.target: $DATABASE$

segment.source: Name of the Recovery database.
segment.target: Name of the Recovery database.

segment.source: Resume the instance of the Administration and Monitoring Website
segment.target: Resume the instance of the Administration and Monitoring Website

segment.source: On the server that is running the Administration and Monitoring Website, use the Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager console to start the Administration and Monitoring Website.
segment.target: On the server that is running the Administration and Monitoring Website, use the Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager console to start the Administration and Monitoring Website.

segment.source: To automate this procedure, you can use Windows PowerShell to run a command that is similar to the following:

segment.target: To run this command, you must add the IIS module for Windows PowerShell to the current instance of Windows PowerShell.
